ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: group thinking, critically thinking about your own work, research question design

EDST 400 is a really challenging and rewarding class that teaches you how to imagine and create a piece of new scholarly work in the area of education. You will learn how to find a topic you care about, design a methodology, and construct a powerful literature review. For me, this was the first time I created an independent project in the social sciences  the instructions and your mentor are so helpful along the way in helping build your capacity to do this work.

I learned how to budget my time and plan out a timeline for a major project. I learned how to develop appropriate expectations for a thesis project, and how to incorporate feedback from peers and instructors in meaningful and helpful ways

The largest task this semester was to prepare a literature review, and I received plenty of resources, guidance and feedback during the process. This course was also my first exposure to the institutional review board process for research approval.
How to pose a good research question and set up a social/behavioral research study + write a literature review
education studies capstone, independent research, how to give and receive feedback and build knowledge in a specific subject area
Worked on the capstone! Helpful in teaching me how to tackle such a large project.
The fall semester of writing the capstone class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The highlight of EDST 400 is the teaching staff!  TZB and Erica are deeply invested in us and our growth.  I'm very grateful to have the opportunity to pursue the capstone under their care; they have each helped make this challenging project immensely rewarding.
group work was strong and group support strong; could have used more time writing independently toward benchmarks

YAY numerous opportunities for (and helpful guidance on how to provide) peer feedback!!! YAY supportive community!! YAY helpful week-by-week guidance on our capstone projects!! Ed Studies does such a great job of giving students the support we need to complete quality capstones. I loved this course!

It's hard to evaluate this course along strengths and weaknesses because most of the work is you doing your independent reading, thinking, and writing. Perhaps for an area of improvement, as an alternate for submitting written idea modules, students can meet in pairs to present their idea module for that week (requiring the same organization of thought) but directly to another student so that they can complicate/deepen their thinking on the spot.

strengths: the peer editing is awesome- definitely helped me tremendously and opened my eyes to the strengths and weaknesses of my own capstone! and the capstone 'pitches' were super helpful too!

weaknesses: sometimes it felt like class time could have been used in more efficient ways- I would have liked to have had open class sessions where people just come to work on their projects for a set, focused amount of time, as opposed to discussing stuff not entirely relevant to our individual projects

The strengths are that the expectations are clearly delineated and explained during lecture and strong examples are shared via canvas. 

We also work in small groups a lot, which helps because feedback is from diverse perspectives.

This course provided a great basis for conducting a capstone. However, there were myriad unnecessary assignments that contributed more to cumulative stress and busy work than actual progression of our capstones.

Peer review sessions weren't always super helpful and felt a bit dragged out (I really liked the commenting ones toward the end, but gained less from the in-class workshopping  it's hard to fully understand someone's problem in 30 minutes, so most of the time is spent either saying things I'm not at all sure about or trying to understand what's going on)

strengths: very responsive to student feedback and built to help us do what we want with our projects. great level of honesty regarding where we were all at with our projects, highly appreciated!

weaknesses: it would have been great if idea modules had been due on fridays

This class made the capstone feel a bit less independent than I had expected it to be. I found myself kind of feeling like it was just another class with assignments due every week, which meant I didn't spend much time thinking/working on it in my own way, but rather was kind of pulling stuff together each week so I could submit something. I also think it might've been helpful to receive feedback from both TZB and Erica, rather than only one through the whole semester, though I understand this might just be too much work on their part.

It's great to have a dedicated class for working on the capstone to provide structure to a really big project. A strength was the pacing of the assignments throughout the semester that broke the work down into more manageable pieces. A weakness was it oftentimes felt like there were too many cooks in the kitchen when we did multiple rounds of peer feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i thought this course consumed a lot of time when all of it wasn't necessary

YES!! No matter how scared you are to begin the capstone process, this class will give you the tools and human support you need to create an amazing project! It's a lot of work, especially at the beginning of the semester, but it's WORTH IT.

For me, this course was so challenging because I didn't have a clear idea of what I wanted to do at the beginning. I had an idea that I thought might be good that (it turns out, after actually reading the literature) wasn't turning out how I had originally envisioned. After about a month and a half, after talking to friends and experts in that area, I settled on a project idea. Because I got started so late, I felt like I was playing catchup pretty much all semester. It was really challenging work. It is also super rewarding. I would recommend this to other students, but I would strongly suggest that you really figure out a solid project idea before you walk into class on the first day (something that  after reading some literature  is both doable and feasible). With that said, you need to be willing to put in the work for this class.

yes, if you're an ed studies scholar, you should def take this course- it sets you up to plan out and actually work on your capstone for a full year- especially helpful if you have a second thesis to complete in the fall, because this capstone process is so structured with tzb's help, that it is possible to apply the same approach to your thesis, making everything that much more manageable
Absolutely. Working on the Ed Studies Capstone alongside peers and under the guidance of Professor Zemach-Bersin is helping me gain confidence as a researcher.
Absolutely
It is a required course.

I would recommend only to students in the Education Studies program who have chosen a topic they are interested in exploring further in depth. They must be committed to this topic and motivated to research and read about it. It can seem like a lot of work that does not directly relate to your capstone at times, but can be helpful depending on your project.

extras.title: EDST 400 01 - Advanced Topics in Ed Studies
